title: Darpana Academy of Performing Arts
text:
Darpana Academy of Performing Arts is a school for <a href="performing%20art">performing art</a>s in <a href="Ahmedabad">Ahmedabad</a>, Gujarat, established by <a href="Mrinalini%20Sarabhai">Mrinalini Sarabhai</a> and <a href="Vikram%20Sarabhai">Vikram Sarabhai</a> in 1949, it has been directed by their daughter <a href="Mallika%20Sarabhai">Mallika Sarabhai</a> for the last three decades. The school organises a three-day Interart, the "Vikram Sarabhai International Arts Festival" at Ahmedabad, every year. It celebrated its golden jubilee on 28 December 1998, with the announcement of the annual "Mrinalini Sarabhai Award for Classical Excellence", in the field of classical dance.
Naming.
While "darpana" is the <a href="Hindi">Hindi</a> word for "mirror", the use here also references the "Abhinaya Darpana", "The Mirror of Gestures", <a href="Nandikeshvara">Nandikeshvara</a>'s ancient text upon Indian stage-craft and dance.
History.
The Darpana Academy of Performing Arts was founded in Ahmedabad, <a href="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>, <a href="India">India</a> by <a href="Vikram%20Sarabhai">Vikram Sarabhai</a> and his wife <a href="Mrinalini%20Sarabhai">Mrinalini Sarabhai</a>.
The work in using arts foe social change began at Darpana in the 1960s. Darpana’s puppeteers started working with the central ministry of rural development in teaching village women the use of smokeless stove. The theatre department then run by <a href="Kailash%20Pandya">Kailash Pandya</a> created a play called Ma to rally people to the war effort. <a href="Mrinalini%20Sarabhai">Mrinalini Sarabhai</a>, in a radical departure from the spiritual core of the classical <a href="Bharat%20Natyam">Bharat Natyam</a> used the style to talk of the horror of dowry violence. Over the years two departments were established to focus the work of using the arts for change. Darpana for Dvelopment in 1980, today run by actor activist <a href="Jignesh%20Patel">Jignesh Patel</a>, and Darpana Communication in 2001 run by film maker Yadavan Chandran. In addition, in 2009 CRANTI (Citizens Resource and Action Initiative) was formed to give practical guidance to citizen to use the laws and tools available to them to fight their own battles, and to train people in the use of the Right To Information Act to solve daily problems of access and justice, run by Bharatsinh Jhala. 
During the last three decades, these departments have worked on over 51 projects all over India, reaching out to over 12.5 million people. The work has been in areas ranging from <a href="public%20health">public health</a>, <a href="women%E2%80%99s%20empowerment">women’s empowerment</a>, <a href="gender%20issues%20and%20education%20to%20the%20environment">gender issues and education to the environment</a>, <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a>, <a href="communal%20harmony">communal harmony</a>, <a href="good%20governance">good governance</a>, citizen’s participation in democracy, race, <a href="gender%20and%20disability">gender and disability</a>. Through the use of television and film, theatrical and <a href="street%20performances">street performances</a>, <a href="quizzes">quizzes</a> and <a href="debates">debates</a>, <a href="puppets">puppets</a> and <a href="board%20games">board games</a>. They have been able to effectively talk about a range of sensitive issues from <a href="women%20and%20violence">women and violence</a>, to <a href="religious%20intolerance">religious intolerance</a>, the <a href="Natural%20environment">environment</a>, <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a>, <a href="corruption">corruption</a> and <a href="justice">justice</a>.
The academy received <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> sponsorship to offer Artist Residency programs in 1999-2000 and 2005-2007. The academy was also listed by UNESCO an institution active in the "Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage", and thereby invited to attend the subsequent Intergovernmental Committee meetings.
In 1962, <a href="Achyut%20Kanvinde">Achyut Kanvinde</a> was commissioned by Sarabhai to design the building of the academy.
Activities.
The academy offers courses in Indian classical dance <a href="Bharatanatyam">Bharatanatyam</a>, Indian Classical Vocal, <a href="Mridangam">Mridangam</a>, Violin and Flute, puppetry and martial art <a href="Kalaripayattu">Kalaripayattu</a>. Its departments range from performance and teaching of the arts, to the use of performance and arts as development communication, through face-to-face impact and software production.
The Drama Section, under acting duo <a href="Kailash%20Pandya">Kailash Pandya</a> and <a href="Damini%20Mehta">Damini Mehta</a>, is responsible for more than 100 productions of a wide variety.
Darpana attracted young writers and staged their first scripts, making them an integral part of production efforts. Some of the names can be mentioned as <a href="Madhu%20Rye">Madhu Rye</a>, <a href="Labhshankar%20Thakar">Labhshankar Thakar</a>, <a href="Shrikant%20Shah">Shrikant Shah</a>, <a href="Subhash%20Shah">Subhash Shah</a>, <a href="Chinu%20Modi">Chinu Modi</a>, and <a href="Hasmukh%20Baradi">Hasmukh Baradi</a>. It also conducted theatre-training courses for over two decades.
Its research wing, Janvak, published monographs like Goverdhan Panchal's on <a href="Bhavai">Bhavai</a>. Darpana has also built an experimental thrust auditorium, Natrani, reminiscent of Greek amphitheatres, on the banks of the river Sabarmati.
